awd_titl_txt: CC* Regional: Sun Corridor Network ? Arizona Community College Research Expansion
awd_abstract_narration:
Northern Arizona University (NAU) is a founding member of the Sun Corridor Network (SCN) along with Arizona State University (ASU) and the University of Arizona (UA).  SCN delivers research and education networking to Arizona's research universities through high-speed connections and Internet2. Research and specialized network connectivity at Arizona community colleges are limited and generally unavailable to academic or to specialized technical programs. This project connects one of the nation's largest community college systems and the northern NAU collaborator to SCN. Network expansion to Arizona's community colleges enables research and education connectivity and support to the students and faculty of Maricopa Community College County District's Estrella Mountain Community College (Goodyear, AZ), Chandler-Gilbert Community College (Chandler, AZ), Phoenix College (Phoenix, AZ) and Coconino Community College, (Flagstaff, AZ). The network expansion advances the use of science-oriented workflows, high performance computing in undergraduate research, instrument sharing, STEM education, and homework gap connectivity and introduces wide area and campus networking capacities that align with cybersecurity academic requirements. 

NAU and SCN will improve campus network performance, increasing external connectivity to each campus by connecting them to SCN as a regional aggregator. This leverages a strong existing regional relationship with NAU, a leader in rural and online programs and services. The proposal emphasizes outreach to determine needs and requirements, followed by design, workshops, and science network implementation. By building new collaborations and by expanding connectivity, NAU and SCN improve undergraduate science and technical instruction for over 200,000 students in the Phoenix metropolitan area and northern Arizona.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dedicated science and research networks have become indispensable for promoting undergraduate research and advancing STEM education in community colleges throughout the United States. Community colleges are renowned for their commitment to accessibility and inclusivity in higher education, and they recognize the transformative potential of networks in empowering faculty and expanding students' educational opportunities. This project, in particular, has established cyberinfrastructure to enhance access to undergraduate science and technical instruction, as well as undergraduate research, for over 200,000 students in the Phoenix metropolitan area and Coconino County in Northern Arizona.

The project focused on creating high-performance dedicated science networks at four community colleges: Estrella Mountain Community College, Chandler-Gilbert Community College, Phoenix College, and Coconino Community College. These campus-based science networks are interconnected with the Sun Corridor regional education and research network (SCN), operated by the public universities in Arizona. The initiative aimed to develop sustainable methods for operating science networks, improving science-oriented workflows, and providing access to high-performance computing, large-capacity data storage, and transfer systems to enhance STEM education and undergraduate research opportunities.

Furthermore, the project aimed to extend campus networking capabilities in Arizona through public and private wireless networks.  The project established wireless service and network access for students via Coconino Community College in Page, AZ, and at 11 Chapter Houses and agricultural stations in the Navajo and Hopi Nations. These cost-effective and easily maintained solutions proved crucial during the COVID-19 pandemic and continue to benefit students pursuing educational and STEM-related activities while also enabling researchers to collect field data through various sensors and data upload stations.

Recognizing the limited financial and technical resources available to participating community colleges, the project prioritized affordability, sustainability, and extensibility. Through close collaborations among college and university administrators, a sustainable approach was developed, leveraging the SCN and Arizona's public universities for regionally managed authorization, data transfer, computing, and storage systems. This approach alleviates support burdens on the technical staff of community colleges while establishing a scalable model for dedicated STEM education and research that can be easily adopted by other small colleges in Arizona and beyond.

Northern Arizona University (NAU), a designated Hispanic Serving Institution, played a leading role in this project. In support of the initiative, NAU, in collaboration with the SCN, established the Arizona Attainment Alliance Collaborative Research Network (A++CRN) for seamless access to high-performance computing, data storage, instrumentation, research software applications, and DTN (Data Transfer Node) services. A++CRN is available to faculty at Arizona community colleges and regional Tribal colleges. These resources provide faculty with cost-free access to robust software tools, instrumentation, and expertise, enabling the development of STEM education courses, facilitating undergraduate research, and fostering peer collaborations for future collaborations in teaching and research activities.
